conclusion: Understanding the Stirling cycle involves four processes: A→B (Isothermal expansion), B→C (Adiabatic expansion), C→D (Isothermal compression), D→A (Adiabatic compression).
In an isothermal process, the temperature of the gas remains constant, meaning the average kinetic energy of the gas molecules is constant.
Since the temperature is constant in isothermal processes, the rate distribution curve will not change.
In an adiabatic process, there is no heat exchange with the surroundings, and the internal energy of the gas changes due to work done on or by the gas.
The temperature of the gas changes in an adiabatic process: it increases during adiabatic compression and decreases during adiabatic expansion.
The rate distribution curve of the gas molecules is sensitive to temperature changes; thus, it will change during adiabatic processes.
During the process D→A, which is an adiabatic compression, the temperature of the gas increases.
An increase in temperature during process D→A leads to a change in the rate distribution curve, resulting in a broader and more spread-out curve.
The rate distribution curve of the gas molecules changes during the process D→A because the temperature increases during this adiabatic compression.
The final answer is: Yes, the rate distribution curve of the gas molecule does change during the process D to A.
